title: How to Grow Hydrangea from Cuttings
original_title: How to Grow and Care for Hydrangea make plant a cutting
content: hi this is protolith channel and we're talking about making cuttings from hydrangeas today so you'll want to take a bead hydrangea plant and cut off some leaves like this with a stem and then you'll need a pair of scissors and first thing you will do is take these two leaves and cut them off close like this then you're left with this now go inside here and cut this off just like that and here we have just two leaves left then we fold them up and cut them in half like this and here is our cutting then we take it and put it in the water and leave it in the water for a half a day if you really want this to route fast you can use some route toner but a half-day in the water world will work just fine then take some well joint draining soil like this and this is where we'll put our cutting on the side so you'll want to take something like a pencil or a pen or a small stick and make three holes like this in a pot this size three holes is enough you can do more in a bigger pot then you take your cuttings and you stick it in the hole down to the node that you cut off earlier and then you pack around gently like this and you take another cutting and you put it in and pack down around and take your last little cutting here and yes shoot him right in the hole there and pack it down a little bit then at first make sure it's well watered and moist and keep it in a kind of a not a really dark place but a shady place and it will route after a while you'll have some new hydrangeas thank you very much

title: How to Grow Hydrangea from Cuttings
original_title: You can grow hydrangeas from cuttings
content: if you're interested in heirloom and pass-along plants like I am old home sites and properties like this are perfect resources but make sure you get permission from the landowner as always today we're going to take some cuttings from this wonderful old mophead hydrangea and a few things you want to keep in mind number one always collect green branches on these mop heads they're the ones that are going to be most likely to form the roots and we'll cut this one in two always at an angle so that we get some foliage on both of these stems now these stems are about three or four maybe five inches long and just a perfect size for taking cuttings so we took our hydrangea cuttings and now we're ready to do what's called sticking the cuttings and that is simply putting them in a medium so they'll grow roots notice that I transported the cuttings in a ziplock bag that's so they wouldn't lose moisture and be too dry to work with and the first thing I want to do is remove the foliage until there are only one or two pairs of leaves left and we'll take a little more of material off of the stem always cut at an angle and then remove half of each of these existing leaves now we're ready to stick the stem of the cutting down into a hormone that will induce root initiation and root growth it's just right down into the potting soil and that's all there is to it and after a few weeks of being indoors and in in direct sunlight what you'll see on the cuttings is new growth forming and new growth is a good indication of root formation and that means your hydrangea cuttings are off and running for get it growing I'm Kerry Hefner with the LSU AG center

title: How to Grow Hydrangea from Cuttings
original_title: How to Plant Hydrangeas
content: hi I'm Wade James here at the group having a home garden can be both fun and rewarding I want to thank you for purchasing the group product this video will show you how and when to plant your shrubs in your home garden let's head to my garden and see how this is done planting the right time of year is important to your plants overall success if you purchase start product before the seasons last frost it'd be best to store your plant in a cool and dark location such as a garage or a basement until those freezing temperatures and frost subsides when it comes time for planting carefully title: How to Grow Hydrangea from Cuttings
original_title: How to grow Limelight Hydrangeas (Hydrangea Paniculata or Tree Hydrangea)
content: welcome to Hort tube my name is Jim Putnam and this is a limelight hydrangea [Music] this is the beautiful lime green and white flowering limelight hydrangea limelight hydrangea is a hydrangea paniculata which are sometimes referred to as tree hydrangeas and you can see behind me that this one is maybe 14 feet right now so they get quite large they're listed on a lot of websites to 6 to 8 feet in height and that's probably true that you can keep them in that height range but if you let it go over time it's going to become a small tree hydrangea paniculata is including limelight are extremely cold hardy these things grow in the vast majority of the United States they'll grow all the way up to zone 3 and down to zone 9 limelight is very fast growing once it's established it will probably put on 2 perhaps even three feet of growth in a single season before it flowers in the summer unlike the big leaf hydrangeas hydrangea paniculata czar definitely Sun loving plants I've got these two limelight hydrangeas planted an absolute full Sun they bake from early in the morning until late in the evening lamb light could be pruned into a small tree on the corner of your foundation I don't think you'd probably want this plant along your foundation it would end up covering up the windows you'd have to do so much pruning on it it wouldn't flower very much you'd constantly be pruning the flower buds off lime light makes a fantastic border plant and I think that's really the best use for this plant I've used these two for that purpose right here this has created a nice wind barrier and even when they lose their leaves in the winter time they're actually still quite thick so the main features of limelight hydrangeas is they start off with these lime green flowers which over time become very very bright white and it creates a two-tone color across the plant these right here I don't know if you're going to see that directly in here these have been tree formed and are now in the twelve to fourteen foot range it can be pruned off from the top in the wintertime these could probably be cut in half and be kept as a much smaller shrub these bloom on new growth which i think is fantastic because you can prune them in the winter time the other thing about them blooming on new grow is I can go in here and break off some of these flowers and I likely have enough time for this branch to actually give me two new branches and flower again before the end of summer I've included videos in the description of this video for planting woody trees and shrubs you're really just not going to have a problem with limelight as long as you don't put it in an area that's going to stay wet all the time or mound the mulch up on the base of them over time that could be an issue super easy plant just follow some basic best practices planting instructions and you should be fine hydrangea paniculata is as a group are very drought tolerant once they're rooted into the ground but with that said this thing's in full bloom in early to mid summer and if it wasn't getting some additional water when it was in full bloom it would almost certainly start to lose some leaves you'd see a lot of yellow leaves on this it'd be shedding the flowers would be much smaller perhaps so during that period of time in late spring or early summer if your area becomes dry you'll want to drag a water hose over to these and give them some extra water I fertilize these lime lights in the late winter right before they started to wake up with just a slow-release fertilizer it's about midsummer now and it should be running out it was a fertilizer that last three to four months that's kind of ideal I want the fertilizer running out by midsummer so they can start to wind down and go dormant naturally lime light could be pruned pretty much any time you would need to prune it I don't think you would hurt it probably the best time to do severe pruning on it would be in the late winter or early spring before it starts to wake up the nice thing about hydrangea paniculata is they bloom on new growth and not on old growth like the other varieties of hydrangeas so you can prune these in the winter time and still have flowers you can't do that on hydrangea macrophylla Zoar the big leaf hydrangeas that you can do some additional pruning pruning on it during the season and after these blooms start to fade in midsummer in my area I could actually take these off and I probably have enough time for this thing to flush back out and bloom one additional time in September or October in my area we really don't see a lot of pests on limelight hydrangeas there's a little leaf spot on this and I could find a few places where some things have chewed on it just not that big of a deal it seems to resist most of those types of problems it would be susceptible to root rot if you put it in an area that just stayed wet all the time I think that would not be advisable hydrangea paniculata are definitely more deer resistant than big leaf hydrangeas big leaf hydrangeas they'll absolutely eat them to the ground they tend to stay away from these a little more but if deer are a big concern for you you might only plant one of these and just see how it goes before you put a lot of them in at one time so what are you waiting for even you can grow the stunningly beautiful very long flowering limelight hydrangea thank you for watching my video and if it was helpful please hit the like button and subscribe to my channel for future videos also comment below with any questions you have about hydrangeas thanks for watching

content: they're big blooms enhance every landscape and make sensational bouquets if summer can boil down to one amazing blossom it would be the hydrangea hydrangeas are one of the most popular flowering plants in the world they grow easily in many climates and produce a multitude of large flowers that bloom into the fall you can commonly find them in red blue light and dark purple pink and white this flowering shrub grows from four to eight feet the climbing variety can reach upwards a twenty feet and higher hydrangeas can be relished from summer to early fall prime time for planting is early summer a fall but it's okay to plant hydrangeas in the early spring there's no need to prune hydrangeas unless they're overgrown or unsightly in each year make sure to remove any dead stems or spent blooms hydrangeas look great both in pots and groups in a garden if your garden has a combination of shade and full Sun like at the base of a tree they'll be quite happy and the climbers will cling nicely to arbors trellises or screams its leaves can be made into sweet tea which is common in Japan and Korea as a wedding bouquet hydrangeas declare their magnificence in a stately yet rustic way they commonly last as cut flowers from five to ten days puffed up with eye catching colors hydrangeas are a perfect backdrop in the garden and will brighten any home

content: I'm down the Emery from Glover nursery in West Jordan Utah today we're talking about white hydrangeas hydrangeas can vary in color depending on soil chemistry if they have an alkaline soil they tend to be pink if they have an acid soil they turn blue but some can be reliably white no matter what the soil conditions I have a few of those here on the table this one is called Annabelle hydrangea this is ice crystal oak leaf hydrangea you can see why it gets the name Oakley and this one is Pee Wee oak leaf hydrangea a shorter more compact version these hydrangeas are not nearly as dependent on soil chemistry to keep their color the other thing I like about them is they're much more cold tolerant here in Utah we have a hard time keeping the mophead hydrangeas going but the PJs and Annabelle's and oak leaves do very well so try one of those and you'll have lovely white blooms for most of the summer thank you this is Donna Emery from glamour nursery

content: hey guys I'm planting a hydrangea this morning I'm actually out of my parents house my mom and I were walking through the gardens the other night and she showed me this spot and said that she might like a nice hydrangea and I happen to have this beautiful Gatsby star oak leaf hydrangea at my house and I thought it would be really really pretty this is a perfect spot for it it gets a dappled Sun and it'll have quite a bit of room to grow so this is going to be kind of a basics video and how to properly plan to shrub if you're a beginner gardener I hope it helps you out if you're more seasoned I hope it's a good refresher or it might be old news to you but let's just get started so the first thing you're going to want to do is dig a hole about twice the width of the can and about the same day my hole is dug it's nice and big I think I think it's big enough I did run across a few things you should always check to see if you've got you know irrigation lines where those are at before your digging and I had a couple of small roots because we're right beneath the tree but I was surprised I didn't run into anything bigger so before I actually take the plant out of its pot I'm going to test the level because I don't want the root ball to be lower than the current soil level because we don't want water running in toward the crown of the plant because that can rot woody stemmed plants I'm going to set it in the hole it looks pretty good I'm going to add probably two inches of soil to bump it up a little bit if anything you want that root ball just a tiny bit higher or right at soil level I'm kind of dealing with a slope - it looks like it starts higher and gets lower so I want to be mindful of that next I'm going to remove my hydrangea from the can and then I'm going to rough up its route memory just a little bit just gently with my fingers then I'm going to place it in the hole and I'm going to stand back and see if I like the angle its face I think it looks pretty good I think it's going to fill in the space really beautifully so now I'm going to backfill around the root ball and I'm going to make sure to pack it in really tight to eliminate any air pocket it's always a good idea to add a nice layer of mulch when you're done planting because it helps retain moisture and it helps keep the roots cooler and it looks really pretty my parents had a nice big pile of mulch out back so I just used my hydrangea can and went got a scoop so I'm just going to add a nice layer the last thing I'm going to do is water it in really really well and I think that's the most important thing the first year that you have a brand new shrub is to keep it really well watered grab my watering can so those are the steps on how to properly plant a shrub I hope you guys learn something this is a little bit precarious today because this spot is in a kind of a weird spot I have balcony stairs right here a big tree right in front of me and right here is a rock wall with a nice good sized drop so I was trying real hard not to fall down fall off the wall that would not make for a nice video so anyway thank you guys so much for watching and we will see you in the next video bye

content: [Music] how to grow hydrangeas in Ontario [Music] hydrangeas are deciduous shrubs that produce pink or blue flowers also known as big leaf or French hydrangeas these shrubs are Hardy up to US Department of Agriculture plant hardiness zone six which includes much of southern Ontario of Canada colors [Music] the color of a hydrangea will depend on the soil where it's grown if your soil is acidic the plant will produce blue flowers while alkaline soil results in pink blooms the presence of aluminum in the soil is what determines the coloration according to the Clemson University Cooperative Extension light plant your hydrangeas in a place that gets Sun in the morning but shade in the afternoon planting in hot dry locations will result in stunted growth and no flowers moisture hydrangeas should be planted in well-drained organic soil keep the soil around your hydrangea moist at all times but do not over water Sakhi your waterlogged soil can promote root rot or other diseases

title: How to Grow Hydrangea from Cuttings
original_title: How to Plant Hydrangeas in the Fall Season : Grow Guru
content: I'm Donna Emery from Glover nursery in West Jordan Utah and I'm planting a hydrangea this is an ice crystal oak leaf hydrangea a very cold hardy variety and we're choosing to plant this in the fall if I were planting a mophead hydrangea or one of the more tender ones I'd opt for a spring planting if I could or at least an early fall planting to allow it to become established before the cold weather hits but anytime the grounds not frozen you can plant most hardy plants this soil has already been amended with a good organic compost so I don't need to add any more to it and anybody who's ever gardens in Utah will know already that I've amended this soil previously because normally Utah soil doesn't look this good loosening the sides I want my hole to be about twice the diameter of the pot don't dig a deep hole you don't want to plant the plant too deep I'm gonna get some good starter fertilizer put a handful of it in and around that hole sprinkle some over here if you're planting in the fall you'll want to use less fertilizer you want to promote root growth but not shoot growth just in time for cold weather and this plant has a few funny branches so I'm gonna get rid of those that one's not necessary let's see how the rest of it does well the rest of it looks okay we're going to turn the plant on its side and support it while I pull the plant pot off check for depth it's a little bit deep most sides have most plants have a good side and a bad side so I think I'll find the best side and start back going tamp the soil lightly don't overly compact it but firm it around the roots then I'm checking to make sure I don't have any soil on top of that original root ball I want to be able to see those roots when I'm finished or just a light dusting of soil what it needs now is a good thorough watering followed by a second watering about an hour later and before I leave I'm going to take any tags or string off of this plant I don't want to risk girdling the plant so off comes the identification tag I can make a plant label for it if I need to know what variety it is here's our hydrangea great for fall planting or spring planting I'm Donna Emery from Glover nursery
